channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Why incentives work — or don’t, and more: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01269-6

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: Why incentives work — or don’t, and more: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Kids and clinical trials: why the system is failing children
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01028-7

A panel of physicians and researchers discusses the reasons for the paucity of trials, the effect it has on patients and how the approval process for paediatric drugs could be streamlined.
item.dc:title: Kids and clinical trials: why the system is failing children

item.title: Physicists’ advice on how to swing high at the playground
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01029-6

Models and laboratory swings show the precise motions needed to maximize movement.
item.dc:title: Physicists’ advice on how to swing high at the playground

item.title: Sunshine is transformed into green hydrogen on an ambitious scale
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01031-y

Prototype facility smashes record for converting solar power to hydrogen for its technology category.
item.dc:title: Sunshine is transformed into green hydrogen on an ambitious scale

item.title: Lab-grown fat with texture like the real thing could enrich cultured meat
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01035-8

Approach could make it easier to scale up production of cultivated meat.
item.dc:title: Lab-grown fat with texture like the real thing could enrich cultured meat

item.title: Tracking early lung cancer metastatic dissemination in TRACERx using ctDNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05776-4

Measurements of subclonal expansion of ctDNA in the plasma before surgery may enable the prediction of future metastatic subclones, offering the possibility for early intervention in patients with non-small-cell lung cancer.
item.dc:title: Tracking early lung cancer metastatic dissemination in TRACERx using ctDNA

item.title: Daily briefing: A cellular cause of ageing (and how to reverse it)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01290-9

Ageing speeds up RNA ‘transcription’ — and slowing it down seems to make animals live longer. Plus, how octopuses taste with their arms and hidden life in the Arctic after dark.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: A cellular cause of ageing (and how to reverse it)
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: University of Groningen faces growing calls to reinstate sacked gender-equality researcher
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01286-5

Supporters of Susanne Täuber say her dismissal is a blow for academic freedom, with thousands signing a petition demanding she be allowed to return to work.
item.dc:title: University of Groningen faces growing calls to reinstate sacked gender-equality researcher
item.dc:creator: Anne Gulland

item.title: European Union appeals for interdisciplinary collaboration in new funding model
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01268-7

Brussels hopes that getting scientists from different fields to work together on big issues will bring innovations such as viable hydrogen energy infrastructure to the market more quickly.
item.dc:title: European Union appeals for interdisciplinary collaboration in new funding model
item.dc:creator: Charles Ebikeme

item.title: On the evidence of a trend in the CO<sub>2</sub> airborne fraction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05871-6

On the evidence of a trend in the CO2 airborne fraction
item.dc:title: On the evidence of a trend in the CO<sub>2</sub> airborne fraction
item.dc:creator: Mikkel Bennedsen
Eric Hillebrand
Siem Jan Koopman

item.title: Better than Chanel: perfumed male bees draw more mates
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01033-w

A daub of floral scent gives male orchid bees a leg-up on fathering offspring.
item.dc:title: Better than Chanel: perfumed male bees draw more mates

item.title: Ageing studies in five animals suggest how to reverse decline
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01040-x

Smoothing the speed bumps in an important cellular pathway seems to be implicated in ageing.
item.dc:title: Ageing studies in five animals suggest how to reverse decline
item.dc:creator: Gemma Conroy

item.title: Octopuses hunt by ‘tasting’ with their suckers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01262-z

The receptors that help octopuses sense by touch, plus a round-up of stories from the Nature Briefing.
item.dc:title: Octopuses hunt by ‘tasting’ with their suckers
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: ‘Touch-taste’: how the octopus repurposed its nervous system to hunt
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01013-0

Researchers identify the structural basis for octopuses chemo-tactile sense.
item.dc:title: ‘Touch-taste’: how the octopus repurposed its nervous system to hunt
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: That new car smell has a whiff of health hazards
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01034-9

Surface temperature drives emissions of chemicals that give a newly manufactured vehicle its signature aroma.
item.dc:title: That new car smell has a whiff of health hazards

item.title: A glacier’s catastrophic collapse is linked to global warming
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01030-z

Eleven hikers died after weeks of unusually warm weather led to melting of the Marmolada Glacier in the Alps.
item.dc:title: A glacier’s catastrophic collapse is linked to global warming

item.title: Genomic–transcriptomic evolution in lung cancer and metastasis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05706-4

Computational and machine-learning approaches that integrate genomic and transcriptomic variation from paired primary and metastatic non-small cell lung cancer samples from the TRACERx cohort reveal the role of transcriptional events in tumour evolution.
item.dc:title: Genomic–transcriptomic evolution in lung cancer and metastasis

item.title: Extrachromosomal DNA in the cancerous transformation of Barrett’s oesophagus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05937-5

An analysis of whole-genome sequencing data from patients with Barrett’s oesophagus or oesophageal ademocarcinoma shows that extrachromosomal DNA (ecDNA) is strongly associated with cancer progression, and that a wide range of oncogenes are amplified on ecDNAs.
item.dc:title: Extrachromosomal DNA in the cancerous transformation of Barrett’s oesophagus

item.title: Clonal haematopoiesis and risk of chronic liver disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05857-4

A study shows that clonal haematopoiesis of indeterminate potential is associated with an increased risk of chronic liver disease specifically through the promotion of liver inflammation and injury.
item.dc:title: Clonal haematopoiesis and risk of chronic liver disease

item.title: Chromosomal fragile site breakage by EBV-encoded EBNA1 at clustered repeats
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05923-x

Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV) nuclear antigen 1 is shown to induce breakage of a fragile site on chromosome 11 by binding to a cluster of EBV-like imperfect palindromic repeats.
item.dc:title: Chromosomal fragile site breakage by EBV-encoded EBNA1 at clustered repeats
item.dc:creator: Julia Su Zhou Li
Ammal Abbasi
Dong Hyun Kim
Scott M. Lippman
Ludmil B. Alexandrov
Don W. Cleveland

item.title: Dynamic synchronization between hippocampal representations and stepping
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05928-6

Experiments in rats show that spatial representations in the hippocampus are closely coordinated with the forelimb stepping cycle, particularly when spatial decisions are approaching, and provide insight into how this synchronization supports information processing.
item.dc:title: Dynamic synchronization between hippocampal representations and stepping
item.dc:creator: Abhilasha Joshi
Eric L. Denovellis
Abhijith Mankili
Yagiz Meneksedag
Thomas J. Davidson
Anna K. Gillespie
Jennifer A. Guidera
Demetris Roumis
Loren M. Frank

item.title: Dehydration of a crystal hydrate at subglacial temperatures
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05749-7

A porous organic crystal readily and reversibly adsorbs water, with dehydration occurring well below the freezing point of water, which could be seen by a change in colour.
item.dc:title: Dehydration of a crystal hydrate at subglacial temperatures
item.dc:creator: Alan C. Eaby
Dirkie C. Myburgh
Akmal Kosimov
Marcin Kwit
Catharine Esterhuysen
Agnieszka M. Janiak
Leonard J. Barbour

item.title: Structural basis of sensory receptor evolution in octopus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05822-1

Cryo-electron microscopy analyses reveal adaptations that facilitate the octopus chemotactile receptor’s evolutionary transition from an ancestral role in neurotransmission to detecting greasy environmental agonists for ‘taste by touch’ sensory behaviour.
item.dc:title: Structural basis of sensory receptor evolution in octopus
item.dc:creator: Corey A. H. Allard
Guipeun Kang
Jeong Joo Kim
Wendy A. Valencia-Montoya
Ryan E. Hibbs
Nicholas W. Bellono

item.title: Build-up and dephasing of Floquet–Bloch bands on subcycle timescales
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05850-x

The build-up and dephasing of Floquet-–Bloch bands is visualized in both subcycle band-structure videography and quantum theory, revealing the interplay of strong-field intraband and interband excitations in a non-equilibrium Floquet picture.
item.dc:title: Build-up and dephasing of Floquet–Bloch bands on subcycle timescales
item.dc:creator: S. Ito
M. Schüler
M. Meierhofer
S. Schlauderer

O. E. Tereshchenko
J. Güdde

U. Höfer
R. Huber

item.title: Sensory specializations drive octopus and squid behaviour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05808-z

Octopus and squid use cephalopod-specific chemotactile receptors to sense their respective marine environments, but structural adaptations in these receptors support the sensation of specific molecules suited to distinct physiological roles.
item.dc:title: Sensory specializations drive octopus and squid behaviour
item.dc:creator: Guipeun Kang
Corey A. H. Allard
Wendy A. Valencia-Montoya
Lena van Giesen
Jeong Joo Kim
Peter B. Kilian
Xiaochen Bai
Nicholas W. Bellono
Ryan E. Hibbs

item.title: Foundation models for generalist medical artificial intelligence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05881-4

This review discusses generalist medical artificial intelligence, identifying potential applications and setting out specific technical capabilities and training datasets necessary to enable them, as well as highlighting challenges to its implementation.
item.dc:title: Foundation models for generalist medical artificial intelligence
item.dc:creator: Michael Moor
Oishi Banerjee
Zahra Shakeri Hossein Abad
Harlan M. Krumholz
Jure Leskovec
Eric J. Topol
Pranav Rajpurkar

item.title: Aberrant activation of TCL1A promotes stem cell expansion in clonal haematopoiesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05806-1

Using data from a single time point, passenger-approximated clonal expansion rate (PACER) estimates the fitness of common driver mutations that lead to clonal haematopoiesis and identifies TCL1A activation as a mediator of clonal expansion.
item.dc:title: Aberrant activation of TCL1A promotes stem cell expansion in clonal haematopoiesis

item.title: The little skate genome and the evolutionary emergence of wing-like fins
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05868-1

Skate-specific changes in the epigenome and its three-dimensional organization contributed to the evolution of the batoid fin morphology.
item.dc:title: The little skate genome and the evolutionary emergence of wing-like fins

item.title: Earth shaped by primordial H<sub>2</sub> atmospheres
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05823-0

Thermodynamic modelling shows that Earth’s water, core density and overall oxidation state can be explained by the formation of Earth from planetary embryos with hydrogen-rich primary atmospheres and underlying magma oceans.
item.dc:title: Earth shaped by primordial H<sub>2</sub> atmospheres
item.dc:creator: Edward D. Young
Anat Shahar
Hilke E. Schlichting

item.title: The evolution of non-small cell lung cancer metastases in TRACERx
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05729-x

A longitudinal evolutionary analysis of 126 lung cancer patients with metastatic disease reveals the timing of metastatic divergence, modes of dissemination and the genomic events subject to selection during the metastatic transition.
item.dc:title: The evolution of non-small cell lung cancer metastases in TRACERx

item.title: The evolution of lung cancer and impact of subclonal selection in TRACERx
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05783-5

Analyses of multiregional tumour samples from 421 patients with non-small cell lung cancer prospectively enrolled to the TRACERx study reveal determinants of tumour evolution and relationships between intratumour heterogeneity and clinical outcome.
item.dc:title: The evolution of lung cancer and impact of subclonal selection in TRACERx

item.title: Giant magnetoresistance of Dirac plasma in high-mobility graphene
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05807-0

A Dirac plasma in high-mobility graphene shows anomalous magnetotransport and giant magnetoresistance that reaches more than 100 per cent in a low magnetic field at room temperature.
item.dc:title: Giant magnetoresistance of Dirac plasma in high-mobility graphene

item.title: Antibodies against endogenous retroviruses promote lung cancer immunotherapy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05771-9

In lung adenocarcinoma, antibodies against endogenous retroviruses promote anti-tumour activity, and expression of endogenous retroviruses can predict outcomes of immunotherapy.
item.dc:title: Antibodies against endogenous retroviruses promote lung cancer immunotherapy

item.title: Ageing-associated changes in transcriptional elongation influence longevity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05922-y

Increases in transcriptional elongation speed with age affect organismal lifespan and ageing-related changes could be reversed with lifespan-extending interventions.
item.dc:title: Ageing-associated changes in transcriptional elongation influence longevity
item.dc:creator: Cédric Debès

item.title: Orbital-resolved observation of singlet fission
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05814-1

Time- and angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy is used to observe the primary step of singlet fission with orbital resolution indicating a charge-transfer mediated mechanism with a hybridization of states in the lowest bright singlet exciton.
item.dc:title: Orbital-resolved observation of singlet fission
item.dc:creator: Alexander Neef
Samuel Beaulieu
Sebastian Hammer
Shuo Dong
Julian Maklar
Tommaso Pincelli
R. Patrick Xian
Martin Wolf
Laurenz Rettig
Jens Pflaum
Ralph Ernstorfer

item.title: Astrocyte–neuron subproteomes and obsessive–compulsive disorder mechanisms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05927-7

Analyses of the proteomes of astrocytes and neurons in a cell-specific and subcompartment-specific manner reveal distinct roles for these cell types that are relevant to obsessive–compulsive disorder and perhaps other brain disorders.
item.dc:title: Astrocyte–neuron subproteomes and obsessive–compulsive disorder mechanisms
item.dc:creator: Joselyn S. Soto
Yasaman Jami-Alahmadi
Jakelyn Chacon
Stefanie L. Moye
Blanca Diaz-Castro
James A. Wohlschlegel
Baljit S. Khakh

item.title: Noncoding translation mitigation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05946-4

Combining genome-wide CRISPR screens with massively parallel analyses of human and random DNA sequences reveal a unified mechanism for the surveillance and evolution of translation products from annotated noncoding DNA.
item.dc:title: Noncoding translation mitigation
item.dc:creator: Jordan S. Kesner
Ziheng Chen
Peiguo Shi
Alexis O. Aparicio
Michael R. Murphy
Yang Guo
Aditi Trehan
Jessica E. Lipponen
Yocelyn Recinos
Natura Myeku
Xuebing Wu

item.title: Elusive excited states identified from cutting-edge molecular movies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00980-8

A molecular process called singlet fission might boost solar-cell efficiency, but the mechanism must first be determined. A technique that probes molecules undergoing this process finally reveals the excited states involved.
item.dc:title: Elusive excited states identified from cutting-edge molecular movies
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Musser
Hannah Stern

item.title: The Arctic after dark: a secret world of hidden life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00976-4

An international team braved the far north in January to unlock secrets of how marine organisms tell day from night during the polar winter.
item.dc:title: The Arctic after dark: a secret world of hidden life
item.dc:creator: Randall Hyman

item.title: Epstein–Barr virus is an agent of genomic instability
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00936-y

A protein from Epstein–Barr virus called EBNA1 has been shown to bind to and break human chromosome 11, producing instability in the genome that might cause a predisposition to cancer.
item.dc:title: Epstein–Barr virus is an agent of genomic instability
item.dc:creator: Lori Frappier

item.title: How I use ChatGPT responsibly in my teaching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01026-9

Large language models are here to stay. Here’s how I’m incorporating them, writes Hong Yang.
item.dc:title: How I use ChatGPT responsibly in my teaching
item.dc:creator: Hong Yang

item.title: Daily briefing: How to stem the tide of plastic waste
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01271-y

More-sophisticated policies, smarter recycling and new materials could solve the plastics pollution crisis. Plus, crazy ants’ strange genomes are a biological first and US drug firms say that an abortion-pill ruling threatens the FDA’s authority.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: How to stem the tide of plastic waste
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: The forever family
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00971-9

A place to be happy?
item.dc:title: The forever family
item.dc:creator: Shari Garmise

item.title: Earth’s molten youth had long-lasting consequences
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00979-1

A model shows that key physical properties of our planet, from the density of its iron core to its water, could have been set by interactions between a magma ocean and an early hydrogen atmosphere that was lost to space.
item.dc:title: Earth’s molten youth had long-lasting consequences
item.dc:creator: Sean N. Raymond

item.title: Molecular portraits of lung cancer evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00934-0

Assessing the genetic and cellular changes that underlie human lung cancer as it evolves could aid the development of treatments. The TRACERx project reports data from studies tracking the disease.
item.dc:title: Molecular portraits of lung cancer evolution
item.dc:creator: Tikvah K. Hayes
Matthew Meyerson

item.title: US aims for electric-car revolution — will it work?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01255-y

The Environmental Protection Agency has released draft regulations that set the stage for a huge transition to electric vehicles.
item.dc:title: US aims for electric-car revolution — will it work?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: Genome reveals how the skate got its wings
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00192-0

Genome sequencing, combined with methods for deducing how genomic regions interact, have now provided insight into how the wings that give skates and rays their characteristic shapes evolved more than 200 million years ago.
item.dc:title: Genome reveals how the skate got its wings
item.dc:creator: Chris Amemiya

item.title: How octopuses taste with their arms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01010-3

Ultra-specialized proteins enable octopuses and squids to taste surfaces with their suckers — and these proteins are tailored to each animal’s way of life.
item.dc:title: How octopuses taste with their arms
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Jupiter mission will be first to orbit moon of another planet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01256-x

Europe’s JUICE spacecraft will study three of Jupiter’s four Galilean moons: Ganymede, Callisto and Europa.
item.dc:title: Jupiter mission will be first to orbit moon of another planet
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Plastic waste found chemically bonded to rocks in China
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01037-6

Researchers discover ‘plastic rocks’, probably formed from bags and other litter, in a freshwater creek.
item.dc:title: Plastic waste found chemically bonded to rocks in China
item.dc:creator: Katherine Bourzac

item.title: Extrachromosomal DNA appears before cancer forms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-00982-6

A type of circular DNA called extrachromosomal DNA was thought to be found exclusively in cancer. Its discovery in non-cancerous tissue suggests that it might have an early active role in malignant transformation.
item.dc:title: Extrachromosomal DNA appears before cancer forms
item.dc:creator: David H. Wang

item.title: Postdoc unions can help secure a brighter future
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 11 April 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01007-y

Postdoc unions can help secure a brighter future
item.dc:title: Postdoc unions can help secure a brighter future
item.dc:creator: Neal Sweeney

item.title: eLife: community support for a new publishing model
item.content:encoded:
